items.description: Prohibition was a period in the United States during which the production, sale, and transportation of alcoholic beverages were illegal.
Rather than eliminating drinking, Prohibition reshaped cocktail culture, pushing bars underground instead of shutting them down.
Illegal bars known as speakeasies flourished in cities, operating discreetly to avoid law enforcement.
Hidden entrances and secret passwords, poor lighting and compact spaces, music and dancing, and alcohol served discreetly and quickly.
Cocktails became a way to mask low-quality alcohol rather than showcase fine spirits.
With legal distillation banned, alcohol was often smuggled (bootlegged), illegally distilled as bathtub gin, and inconsistent in quality and strength.
To make these spirits drinkable, bartenders relied on citrus juice, sugar or honey, and strong flavors or spices.
This directly led to the popularity of sweet and sour cocktails.
Cocktails became stronger in flavor, heavily sweetened, and highly dependent on fresh citrus.
Presentation mattered less than drinkability and speed of service.
Many cocktails from this era are bold, acidic, and sweet by design.
Gin-based sours, rum cocktails influenced by Caribbean imports, Champagne cocktails used for disguise and luxury, and simple highballs designed for fast service.
These drinks prioritized speed, concealment, and masking harsh flavors.
Many skilled bartenders emigrated to Europe and Cuba, spreading cocktail knowledge internationally.
American bartending standards declined temporarily, recipes became inconsistent, and much knowledge went undocumented.
When Prohibition ended, traditional bartending knowledge had to be rediscovered.

Prohibition shaped modern cocktails by establishing citrus-driven structures, encouraging innovation under restriction, creating mystique around bar culture, and influencing bar aesthetics still used today.
Modern speakeasy-style bars are directly inspired by this era.

Understanding Prohibition helps bartenders understand why some cocktails are sweet or citrus-heavy, respect historical context, explain cocktail stories to guests, and avoid repeating past mistakes in balance and quality.
